channel.title: Interesting thought
channel.description:
Okay, imagine this. You have 2 giant magnets. I'm talking 50 feet wide and 20 feet thick. Now you turn them to where they are pushing away from eachother. The one that is floating above the other one has something on all sides and above it to keep it to keep it floating directly above the other one.
Now you've got this gap of a few feet in between the bottom magnet and the floating one. What would happen if you were to walk in between the two? Thoughts?

item.title: Interesting thought
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

They make a floating bed like that, iirc

Read full topic

item.description:
@noobs_are_ftw wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:14, topic:374996”][quote author=noobs are ftw link=topic=470964.msg3445128#msg3445128 date=1293382523]

[quote author=noobs are ftw link=topic=470964.msg3444839#msg3444839
date=1293345804]
Get 2 mini magnets and put ur finger in between and there’s ur answer in small scale

I presume that was sarcasm.

nah he was just wrong, the magnets in the original question are repelling in his example they are attracting
[/quote]

I didn’t word right get 2 small ones that repell each other
[/quote]
you couldnt put them either side of your finger, they’d push each other away you’d need to build a small rig to hold them[/quote]

Your point still simpler than 2 giant magnets and a lot cheaper

item.title: Interesting thought
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

noobs are ftw:

Get 2 mini magnets and put ur finger in between and there’s ur answer in small scale

I presume that was sarcasm.

However testing on a smaller scale could be viable, for instance MRIs at Zoos are huge, so just put a mouse in that and the scaling can’t be too far off. Turn it up to max and see if mousey survives.

Read full topic

item.title: Interesting thought
item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

Assuming that they’re both fully charged neodymium magnets with anywhere from 90k-120k Gauss(which would be an approximate amount based on the dimensions you provided), and the area is enclosed in some sort of metallic material capable of retaining magnetic force, the force of the magnets is easily capable of tearing the iron particles in your blood cells completely apart from the lipids that hold them together.

This would result in your body not so much exploding as it would be just “separating”. There’s still no doubt that it would be messy and you wouldn’t survive it.

Read full topic
